Award.AwardTitle: "IDBR: TYPE A" A fluorescence microscope optical insert that creates video-rate 3D imaging capabilities using an innovative "expanded point information content" design
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non Technical Description:
Scientists at the University of Colorado at Boulder will develop a modified biological microscope whose purpose is to demonstrate how a novel approach to optical design, called expanded point information content (EPIC), can convert existing live-cell fluorescence microscopes into fully 3D video-rate imaging instruments at a fraction of the cost and complexity of commercial confocal designs. The new microscope will demonstrate to biologists engaged in studies of live cell dynamics that it will be possible to record high resolution 3D images at speeds an order of magnitude faster than existing microscopes and simultaneously locate features in depth to an accuracy of 70nm or better, without the need to change focus. The project is grounded in the field of computational optics and is based on the premise that, by optically altering the microscope point spread function, much more information about the original three-dimensional sample can be encoded into pairs of simultaneously recorded images and then rapidly retrieved by digital image processing. If this procedure (known as point spread function engineering) is done in a controlled manner, the expanded information from each 3D object point, once processed, will provide biologists with the capability to obtain 3D animations of subcellular dynamic events that occur at video rates or faster.

Technical Description:
In a broader context, the new EPIC approach represents a potentially transformative concept that could revolutionize the way next generation optical imaging instruments are designed, not only in microscopy, but also in other devices such as endoscopes and telescopes. Implementation of the EPIC design requires only simple modifications to a standard optical imaging system, such as inserting a phase plate, adding a second camera and installing a software package. In this project, these modifications will be implemented on a commercial biological microscope. Once completed, the new microscope will be tested by collaborating biologists in challenging studies of living cells. It will also provide the basis for teaching and training young scientists and engineers, providing opportunities for conducting multi-disciplinary training workshops where biology students learn about optical microscopy and image processing, and engineering students learn about challenges in live-cell dynamics investigations. A final planned activity will be to work with collaborating commercial partners to bring the new EPIC microscope add-on system to the marketplace, thereby making it readily accessible to the many hundreds of biologists who use fluorescence microscopes as a primary laboratory tool.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of this project was to demonstrate how our innovative approach to optical design (called expanded point information content) could be used to greatly extend the capabilities of conventional widefield biological microscopes. Specifically, we proposed to develop a prototype optical microscope that uses point spread function (PSF) engineering principles to increase the information content of its images and novel computational image processing techniques to extract this information. The project aims were to demonstrate that the entire three-dimensional volume of a cell or its components could be imaged at high resolution, with no out-of-focus blurring artifacts, all from a single position of focus. This meant that several drawbacks of confocal and 3D widefield microscopy (such as detector pinholes and the need to create multi-focal stacks of images) would be overcome.

We proceeded to successfully build a prototype microscope that did achieve these aims, simply by installing a custom-designed phase plate in the imaging path of a widefield fluorescence microscope, scanning a focused laser spot once across the sample to capture a series of sub-images on a standard CMOS camera, and then processing these sub-images with a specially tailored non-negative least squares optimization algorithm.

Remarkably, a major breakthrough was achieved in the second year of the project that was unforeseen at the time the proposal was written. We discovered that, not only could we image extended volumes from a single plane of focus, we could produce super-resolved fluorescence images of these 3D continuous biological objects. Even more surprisingly, this improved resolution (i.e. greater than the traditional microscope diffraction limit) was achieved uniformly in all three dimensions, overcoming the usual optical phenomenon in which the third or axial (Z) dimension of a 3D image reconstruction always exhibits poorer resolution than the lateral (X-Y) dimension.

With the assistance of the collaborating biologists on our project team, we have experimentally verified 3D super-resolved imaging in a range of biological applications. The accompanying figure shows a comparison of the imaging capabilities of a confocal microscope versus our new expanded information content microscope. Shown are three-dimensional image reconstructions of a portion of a fixed BPAE cell with fluorescent mitochondria surrounding the dark (unlabeled) nucleus. Using the same high-resolution microscope objective (NA 1.4), our new microscope exhibits uniform super-resolution of approximately 100nm in all three dimensions as compared to the 250nm X-Y resolution and 700nm Z resolution of the confocal system. In addition, the new microscope achieved these super-resolved results from a single position of focus, whereas the confocal 3D reconstruction required obtaining a multi-focal stack of 14 successive images.

Broader Impacts

Impact on the principal discipline(s) of the project:

This project challenged long-held assumptions about the ability of biological fluorescence microscopes to resolve continuous object features that are smaller than the diffraction limit of a standard optical system. A new path to super-resolution fluorescence microscopy was demonstrated. Contrary to the general belief that super-resolution imaging requires special fluorophores or excitation processes, our results demonstrate that super-resolution imaging in all three dimensions is possible using continuous biological samples prepared with standard fluorophores on a conventional widefield microscope with only a few modifications. No special photo-activatable fluorophores or complicated illumination patterns are required (as in most existing super-resolution microscope systems).

Impact on other disciplines:

This super-resolution microscopy project clearly demonstrates the power of combining computational image processing with optical system design. Specifically, our interdisciplinary approach uses mathematical modeling tools to describe the information content of a microscope's recorded images and then uses these models to design optical waveplates to expand and enhance the recorded image information content. This recorded image information is then extracted through the development of specially-tailored optimization algorithms to produce super-resolved 3D reconstructions of the biological objects being examined. It is likely that this new approach could impact future development of other optical imaging systems (such as endoscopes, for example).

Other achievements:

These proof-of-principle super-resolution results have recently led to a collaboration with a local microscope development company that is working with our university research team to adapt the new 3D super-resolution technology for implementation on their commercial two-photon microscope system. Using our phase plate and algorithm modification, we were able to produce super-resolved 3D images of dendritic spines in mouse brain sections. This instrument will be introduced to the marketplace toward the end of 2018.

Development of human resources:

Three PhD students, one post-doctoral fellow, one senior research associate, one staff scientist, and one research professor received partial funding from this project.

Students and post docs all received experience and mentoring in presenting talks and posters at international conferences; research paper and grant proposal writing skills; theory development; mathematical modeling; computational image processing; and experimental design and fabrication. All worked with our collaborating biologists to test and evaluate the ability of the new microscope to solve current biological problems.
